Comment: V-coding can‚Äôt exist in a vacuum. It‚Äôs legalized sex slavery that corrections officers not only retain full control over the entirety of the supply chain for, but get to financially profit off of. Trans women have historically been the comfort women of the prison industrial complex, which they must endure without resistance in any way lest their sentence be extended.   It‚Äôs either be sold repeatedly as a sex slave and risk being murdered, or face indefinite solitary confinement and risk death from medical negligence and mistreatment.  Either way, nobody will ever be held accountable anyways and they know that as this has been the case no matter who has been president. This has corrections officers themselves feeling so emboldened by a historical lack of action that 3 of every 4 trans women who have been incarcerated in men‚Äôs prisons have reported being subjected to sexual violence by the corrections officers staffing the prison, so it‚Äôs not just the inmates.   Sounds like quite the attractive racket for any discerning capitalist, American, British, or otherwise.  It‚Äôs in light of this that this program was ended.   This is considered a moral win for MAGA.

Comment: My sister is trans and spent 5 months in prison about a decade back. She is a brave and fierce advocate for SA victims and human rights abuses. She's been through hell and back, seen it all, and survived... But she can barely speak about her time in prison. She's absolutely terrified of experiencing incarceration again.  She is EIGHT YEARS sober, and I'm so proud of her for never giving up and starting each day with optimism and hope. She is such an inspiration to me, I can't even describe it. I'm a SA survivor multiple times over, as well, and she's helped me in my recovery in ways I can't begin to express.  If she can survive, learn, grow, and thrive, those days where I want to give up completely are becoming fewer and farther between. I'm so lucky and so blessed to have her as family.
